events.target_title: Can't create GEnum in Python

note.body: I have implemented support for enums and flags which can inherit from GObject.GEnum. They can be used in GObject.Property. I did it by creating a metaclass for gobject.GEnum and gobject.GFlags and moving some of the code from pyg_enum_add and pyg_flags_add to the metaclass. I also added some tests for this. A patch is attached. I am happy to make revisions if necessary. [enums.patch](/uploads/fd092a89740ab96948f7438a01c711fb/enums.patch)

events.target_title: GIMP 2.10.12 File Dialog Crash

note.body:
It's an issue others are having as well. It's not directly related to GIMP but when I posted this I wasn't aware of that. The issue may need to be fixed in glib-gio as the issue was causing many other things to crash too. I use Cinnamon and my file explorer (Nemo) was crashing as well. Looking at the [wps-office](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/wps-office/) package on AUR you can see posts by other users with the same problem. It appears to be due to an issue with wps office and thumbnail generation.

Once I had debugging symbols installed and was able to pinpoint the cause I just uninstalled wps-office since I rarely use it anyway. It would be nice if issues with external applications did not cause gimp to crash.

events.target_title: Seahorse unable to import pkcs12 certificates in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS
Seahorse unable to import pkcs12 certificates in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS

note.body:
Hi Andre, thank you for your attention ant time looking for this issue.

I understand your point, I'd no intention of filling a duplicated bug, I
just filled the bug on GNOME/Seahorse following the instruction received on
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/seahorse/+bug/1771880/comments/15
which is quoted below (emphasis added):

Jeremy Bicha (jbicha) <https://launchpad.net/~jbicha> wrote on 2018-08-28:
> #15
> <https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/seahorse/+bug/1771880/comments/15>
>
> Seahorse does not support .p12 certificates. It supports GPG and SSH
> certificates.
>
> Thank you for taking the time to report this bug and helping to make
> Ubuntu better.* The issue you are reporting is an upstream one and it
> would be nice if somebody having it could send the bug to the developers of
> the software at **https:/**/gitlab.**gnome.org/**GNOME/seahorse/**issue*s
> <https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/seahorse/issues> . If you have done so,
> please tell us the number of the upstream bug (or the link), so we can add
> a bugwatch that will inform us about its status. Thanks in advance.
> *summary*: - Seahorse unable to import certificates in Ubuntu 18.04
> + Seahorse unable to import pkcs12 certificates
> Changed in seahorse (Ubuntu):
> *importance*: Undecided → Wishlist
>

I may well be wrong (I'm a lawyer, not a developer) but I understand that
this issue is an "Ubuntu bug" not a "GNOME bug", as it apparently just
happens in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS, which is supposed to be supported for 5 years
until April 2023. Nevertheless, I followed the above instruction as the
solution was marked downstream as a mere "wishlist". I assume no one will
spend time trying to fix it, despite de lifespan support of Ubuntu 18.04
LTS is supposed to last 4 years more.

Kind regards,

Angelo

events.target_title: Switch tab doesn't change active canvas in window's name

note.body:
Yes, that's the same root casue. It didn't handle the 'switch-page' event of the GTK NOTEBOOK. Instead, it relys on GDK_FOCUS_CHANGE currently.
When you touch the canvas, it triggers the GDK_FOCUS_CHANGE event and set the correct display. But switch the tab sometimes didn't trigger the GDK_FOCUS_CHANGE event.

events.target_title: jhbuild instructions incomplete

note.body:
On 7/11/19 6:55 AM, Andre Klapper wrote:> Andre Klapper
<https://gitlab.gnome.org/aklapper> commented:
>
> Hmm. Instructions like |cd evince; ./autogen.sh; make; make install|
> which encourage people to blindly copy and paste commands with knowing
> what they are doing is a good way to make people shoot themselves in the
> foot. That's nothing I'd myself ever put onto a page (but I'm not an
> Evince developer).

True, but the alternative is to leave people with little
hint as to how to build evince.  Hence, I believe providing
*some* guidance is better than providing none.  I had to look at
autogen.sh code to guess at what it did, but I wasn't sure.
Then I had to google a lot to find:

  http://library.gnome.org/devel/jhbuild/stable/getting-started.html.en

where I found this formula and I had to assume that this is
what to do. If using that formula is not valid, then the
documents need to provide a formula that is, with cautions
about what can go wrong.  On example of such a caution is
that that formula could produce the output:

  autoreconf: running: /usr/bin/autoconf --force
  configure.ac:77: error: possibly undefined macro: AM_GNU_GETTEXT_VERSION
        If this token and others are legitimate, please use
m4_pattern_allow.
        See the Autoconf documentation.
  configure.ac:80: error: possibly undefined macro: AM_GNU_GETTEXT
  autoreconf: /usr/bin/autoconf failed with exit status: 1

Which is what happened to me.  What do I do in this case, please?

>
> "This will install the evince executable in ???" depends on what you
> pass to autogen.sh and depends on your distribution\s default places,
> hence I see nothing to generalize here either...
>

So there's no possible explanation of how using `git clone`
can allow the user to build evince.  Then why mention it?

-regards,
Larry

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libsoup/blob/master/libsoup/soup-session.c#L2028

Given that my test case involves playing a DASH stream and then blocking the server using iptables to verify that the GStreamer pipeline handles the error correctly, my guess is that libsoup is retrying a failed GET and that is adding a SOUP_MESSAGE_RESTARTING to the message queue

events.target_title: libsoup resets the GCancellable passed to soup_session_send

note.body:
Hi Dan,

I've implemented your suggestion of chaining the user-supplied cancellable to the internal cancellable via g_cancellable_connect(), and this fixes the problem I was having with dashdemux.

I can prepare a patch, but I'm not really sure how to write a regression test for this, I spent some time today trying to come up with a test that would cause libsoup to reset the cancellable, but I haven't managed it so far. Basically I'm trying to write a test that hits this line:

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libsoup/blob/master/libsoup/soup-session.c#L4436

since that will cause a message with a status of SOUP_MESSAGE_RESTARTING to be added to the queue, and that should trigger the reset. If anyone has any ideas about what condition will exercise this code I'd be very interested in hearing it.

Tom

events.target_title: libsoup resets the GCancellable passed to soup_session_send

note.body:
I have unfortunately been unable to come up with a test case that reproduces this issue. Looking through the code, it looks like the scenario that causes the SOUP_MESSAGE_RESTARTING to be queued is very much an edge case, it looks like the it could happen if the socket connection is broken prior to it being accepted by the remote server, but none of the existing tests exercise this code path (verified by putting an abort() in the location I mentioned above.

For what it's worth, I'll attach my patch, which does fix the issue I was seeing with dashdemux, the existing tests related to cancellation all pass for me with this change

events.target_title: Encoding auto-detection doesn't work in Meld 3.20 when using GUI to select files
Encoding auto-detection doesn't work in Meld 3.20 when using GUI to select files

note.body:
> Can you also please provide the actual steps you're doing to start a comparison.

Sorry for my panic in the previous post:  
thorough testing has shown that the bug is much less severe than I thought yesterday.

The auto-detection works fine if filenames are specified in command line:
```
   $meld file1 file2
```
This means everything is OK in most use cases: when Meld is invoked from git, from customizable text editors, from user scripts.  
If we compare two directories and double-click on a file, then new file comparison tab is opened, in which auto-detection works fine too.

The bug appears only when file comparison tab is created by GUI dialogue:  
we open tab "New Comparison", press big button "File Comparison" and select files manually,  
and in this new file comparison tab the auto-detection doesn't work.


Interesting example with two tabs comparing the same pair of files:  
We open Meld with command line "$meld file1 file2", everything is displayed correctly (auto-detection does work in the first tab).  
Now go to menu "File -> New comparison -> File comparison" and manually select the same two files.  
Auto-detection in the second tab doesn't work: files are displayed always in the encoding $LC_CTYPE.

----

> If you can, could you please try running `python3` in whatever context Meld 3.20 is installed in, and trying

The output of your python code on my PC:
```
   Unicode UTF-8
   Cyrillic WINDOWS-1251
   Unicode UTF-16
   Unicode UTF-8
   Western ISO-8859-15
   Unicode UTF-16
```
The first 3 encodings printed match my "encodings priority list" entered using `gsettings`.

Mail disappears while writing

note.body:
Sorry for commenting here but there's something with my browser, it won't fully open the comment box down below.

Wanted to say it happens to me too both on **typing a reply** and on **reading a message**.
I noticed it happening especially when the network connection is busy/crowded (downloading files, checking for updates etc) but not only.
Problem happens when anything changes: new message(s) in inbox, message(s) marked as un/read, deleting conversations, are the most obvious and frequent.

As mentioned somewhere here, a workaround for replying is to detach the reply window. However, there is no workaround when reading a message - the display window goes blank with the misleading note **"No conversations selected"** while a conversation **is** selected and the user **was reading** one of the containing messages. One must select another **read** conversation (selecting an unread one would trigger the bug once again if switching between conversations fast enough) and then go back to the desired one (which was already marked as read in the mean time), search for the message they were reading, and hope there would be no more new messages or other sync operations that would trigger the unwanted behavior again. This is extremely annoying.

* version: Geary 0.12.4
* installation: package
* desktop: Cinnamon
* OS: Linux Mint 19.1 x64 with all current Ubuntu Eoan updates
* mail servers: AOL.com, Mail.com

Geary settings:
![Screenshot_from_2019-07-12_13-16-56](/uploads/d3782942d1bd3528822e5cd2560e5412/Screenshot_from_2019-07-12_13-16-56.png)

note.body:
Difference is, issue 352 asks for **same** column text in tooltip **and** only when text is clipped, while I ask (in second part) for **another** column's text regardless of any clipping. But yes, both issues are related to having tooltips in the message list.

**EDIT:**
Let's try some pseudo-code:
```
if (hovering Sender && Sender Mail is hidden && From is hidden)
   {
    if Sender is clipped
      Show tooltip '$Sender\n$SenderMail'
    else
      Show tooltip '$SenderMail'
    }
```

events.target_title: Today Button off-by-one

note.body:
I think step 4. in steps to reproduce should say:
4. The Today-Button is **not** clickable. (Meaning it is grayed out.) 
The correct behavior should be that the today button is clickable anytime "today" is not visible in the current calendar view. But I agree with Beilharz that it should probably never be inactive, and when "today" is already visible in the current view, it should do something to alert the user to where the red "today" timeline is visible currently in their view (like flash it or momentarily make it bolder).
Thanks to the devs for making great free software!

events.target_title: Today Button off-by-one

note.body:
According to NEWS log this bug was likely introduced in:

`Major changes in 3.21.2:`
`* Make the "Today" button insensitive when the current day is visible (Javier Sánches Ochango)`
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calendar/blob/master/NEWS

events.target_title: Test utf8-pointer fails with static build, LTO, optimisations, and new GCC
Test utf8-pointer fails with static build, LTO, optimisations, and new GCC

note.body:
Okay, I investigated the issue a bit more.

Since Ubuntu 19.10 has all three latest versions I decided to test builds on it. Here're the results:

`utf8-pointer` test fails with GCC 9.2.1 and 8.3.0 but succeeds on 7.4.0. Everything else is the same, so I definitely suspect something related to optimisation (-O2) and LTO (both are required to reproduce the issue.)

Here are the logs:

[testlog-gcc7.txt](/uploads/c8959f9ea649ff32d5cec99355fc8039/testlog-gcc7.txt)

[testlog-gcc8.txt](/uploads/5da8d18d32b6cf2e3d987755ac5ca7b6/testlog-gcc8.txt)

events.target_title: Test utf8-pointer fails with static build, LTO, optimisations, and new GCC

note.body: I run the test through gdb and apparently it fails because variable `q` was optimised-out.

events.target_title: Test utf8-pointer fails with static build, LTO, optimisations, and new GCC

note.body:
Well, adding
```
#if defined(__GNUC__) && __GNUC__ > 7
#pragma GCC optimize (1)
#endif
```
to the beggining of `glib/tests/utf8-pointer.c` file obviously fixes the issue, but it's not that portable.

note.body:
For build on host windows witch **msvc** and **msys64/x86_64-w64-mingw32**:
tested for 1.36.0-stable,1.37-beta3,1.38.0-nightly,debug and release,shared and static.  
**CARGO_TARGET_ARGS** must always be defined, mandatory (**cygwin64**,**mingw32**,**msvc**).  
Notice the change definition **LIBRSVG_TARGET_DIR**.  

build **msys64/x86_64-w64-mingw32**:  
./autogen.sh --host=x86_64-w64-mingw32 RUST_TARGET=x86_64-pc-windows-gnu LIBS="-lws2_32 -luserenv" --enable-debug --enable-static --enable-shared  
make  
  
build **msvc**:  
SET "INCLUDE=%INCLUDE%;C:\_lib\vcpkg\src\installed\x64-windows\include;"   
SET "LIB=%LIB%;C:\_lib\vcpkg\src\installed\x64-windows\debug\lib;C:\_lib\vcpkg\src\installed\x64-windows\lib;C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10\Lib\10.0.18362.0\um\x64;C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10\Lib\10.0.18362.0\ucrt\x64;"  
SET "LIBPATH=%LIBPATH%;C:\_lib\vcpkg\src\installed\x64-windows\debug\lib;C:\_lib\vcpkg\src\installed\x64-windows\lib"

rustup set default-host x86_64-pc-windows-msvc

nmake -f Makefile.vc CFG=debug          >>debug.out

is in the files  "\librsvg\m4\introspection.m4" line 23 and "\librsvg\configure"  
**--enable-introspection=[no/auto/yes]**  


I proposed to change from  
RUSTUP_CMD = $(RUSTUP) **default** $(DEFAULT_TARGET)  
to  
RUSTUP_CMD = $(RUSTUP) **run** $(DEFAULT_TARGET) **cargo build**  
and check version RUST for MSVC build like "\librsvg\configure.ac" line 116

```
MINIMUM_RUST_MAJOR=1
MINIMUM_RUST_MINOR=34

rust_version=`$RUSTC --version`
version=`echo "$rust_version" | sed -e 's/^rustc //g'`
major=`echo "$version" | cut -d. -f1`
minor=`echo "$version" | cut -d. -f2`

AS_IF(test "$major" -lt "$MINIMUM_RUST_MAJOR" -o "$minor" -lt "$MINIMUM_RUST_MINOR",
    AC_MSG_ERROR([librsvg needs at rustc version at least $MINIMUM_RUST_MAJOR.$MINIMUM_RUST_MINOR])
)
```
P.S. If I'm wrong, I won't reopen issue anymore

note.body:
I'm seeing the same behavior running Geary under Debian buster with the XFCE desktop.

I think the problem might be that Geary is not dealing well with the jump in system time that occurs after exiting the suspend or hibernate state.   After coming out of suspend or hibernate, there will be a short interval in which networking connectivity is lacking.

Just having geary retry a couple times with a few seconds between tries might be enough to take care of this problem.

events.target_title: Missing "Allow Resizing" dialog checkbox for Drop Shadow
Missing "Allow Resizing" dialog checkbox for Drop Shadow

note.body:
This is not quite the same issue as 2538, although the bug I am reporting is likely the *cause* of 2538. **I will prove it to you.**  If you having marked it "the same" prevents the Gimp programmers from seeing my report(s), please *un*mark it and reopen it, because I searched long and hard for anything about missing "Allow Resizing" checkboxes before reporting it.

This is *not* a "new feature" request.  This is a repair request for a feature that was long part of Gimp, **but has since disappeared**, possibly *only from the English* version of Gimp.  These instructions clearly show that it used to be there:

[How to Use Drop Shadow in GIMP](https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Drop-Shadow-in-GIMP)

Kepa INKubo (thank you) kindly provided a screenshot suggesting a workaround for me, and it shows that the missing "Allow Resizing" box is, again, missing only in the *English* version of Gimp, and extends beyond just the Drop Shadow function.  It extends to the Script-Fu: Xach-Effect, too. (And where else?)

![Gimp-bug-round-2a](/uploads/f695aa649d48f3a6a015b4b9d37e7168/Gimp-bug-round-2a.jpg)

![Gimp-bug-round-2](/uploads/cfd8a63c97450fb4ae4dc1d0011d730b/Gimp-bug-round-2.jpg)

So "Keep Selection" is *not* the same as either "Permitir Redimensionado" or "Allow Resizing", and "Keep Selection" appears to have no effect in Script-Fu: Xach-Effect anyway, although you do get to keep the edge of your shadow, but *only* if you start with a canvas already bigger than your layer to be shadowed, and do some tricky flattening and fuzzy re-selection.

Drop Shadow in English no longer shows any box there at all, although it once did.   "Allow Resizing" also appears to have once been available in "Script-Fu: Xach-Effect, but is no longer there either, *in Gimp English*.  This is likely the *cause* of 2538, and probably some reports you might have involving Script-Fu: Xach-Effect, too.

I'm sure Portuguese is a beautiful language, but it shouldn't be a prerequisite for using Gimp.

events.target_title: Missing "Allow Resizing" dialog checkbox for Drop Shadow

note.body:
PS, thank you for the tip on the "Legacy Drop Shadow" script!  I had not noticed it - once you see "Drop Shadow" in the menu, you don't expect to see others!  How long will a "Legacy Drop Shadow" be supported?

Please inform the people that did this to us, that *removing* the "Allow Resizing" checkbox from *only* the *English* version of the updated Drop Shadow and Xach-Effect were *not* improvements.

Same for me after upgrading from ubuntu 18.10 to 19.04. Gnome was running perfectly fine before and now the whole desktop is laggy as hell. But prominent are the file dialogues and the login screen. When the computer is locked it has the same lag as the file dialogue after entering the password. And it is not only the OPEN action in the file dialogue, it's a general problem with closing the dialogue, even when clicking CANCEL ("Abbrechen" in the attached video). It's a 10 seconds lag! Switching Windows with Alt+Tab lags as well for about a second. I have even damn lags while entering text here, but I can't prove that's a related issue.

events.target_title: Lag and CPU 100% for about 5 seconds whenever selecting a file from a file-dialog

note.body:
Hm strange, not sure exactly what happened, but after fiddling with the gnome extensions a bit, the file dialog lag is now down to 2 seconds and overall performance seems to be improved, there is no lag at all when switching windows now.

What I did was something like

```
sudo apt remove gnome-shell-extension-weather
sudo apt install --reinstall gnome-shell-extension-appindicator #because i set it to ri state before, not knowing it's a gnome-shell dependency
```

And then activated the previously inactive extensions Desktop Icons, Ubuntu Appindicators, Ubuntu Dock in gnome-tweak-tool.

I can't pin it down to one of these actions. But it seems the lags are at least partially due to some fu**ed up extensions stuff and it was not enough to disable all shell extensions.

events.target_title: Include mail from Sent and Archive in Inbox when "Group By Threads" view is enabled

note.body:
More and more software is designed to show messages from Sent and Archive folders in the thread by default. For example Gmail does this. I don't suggest to follow everything Gmail does but in the current landscape of mailclients this could be considered default practice amongst mailclients.

I just tested this with Gmail:

When a remote party sends a mail (mail 1) to Gmail, and the Gmail user replies (mail 2) and archives the thread after replying, and the remote party replies back (mail 3) all 3 messages are shown in the thread in the Inbox.

Additionally:

When a Gmail user sends a new mail (mail 1) to a remote party, and the remote party replies (mail 2) both messages are shown in the thread in the Inbox.

While at it: Yes, Search Folders are meant for this but lack an important feature: see issue #548

events.target_title: Include mail from Sent and Archive in Inbox when "Group By Threads" view is enabled

note.body:
It's not about Gmail though, that was an example. Apple Mail does this (includes messages from all folders), Outlook.com does this, Aqua Mail and Blue Mail (Android mail clients) do this, Mailspring does this. More and more clients do this.

I think this should at least be an option. A conversation (thread) with only the incoming mail (which is the current default behaviour) is no conversation at all. It's a monologue.

events.target_title: S.M.A.R.T not supported for USB disks (that smartmonctl can handle fine) ?

note.body:
If you are only using libatasmart really need a way to pass 
"-d sat" in the command line to let sata disks to be read 

As the name suggests libatasmart only does ATA S.M.A.R.T.,
there is no support for SCSI harddisks. SCSI S.M.A.R.T. is a very different system, support for it should be implemented in
a separate library "libscsismart" if there should ever be
demand for it.

        This library is supposed to be lean and small and thus
        supports only a subset of the S.M.A.R.T. functionality.
        However, I claim that it implements the relevant part of it.
        If you need full control over all S.M.A.R.T. functionality of
        your hardware please refer to Buce Allen's smartmontools.

        libatasmart supports classic ATA/IDE disks (i.e. /dev/hda) as
        well as ATA disks that are connected through a SCSI layer
        (SAT) (such as a SATA /dev/sda).

        USB disks generally don't support SAT and thus generally
        cannot be queried for S.M.A.R.T. data.

note.body: This is happening to me using RGB. It is very annoying and has caused me a lot of additional work. I am creating sprites for a game. I am authoring them in color using a restricted palette. My intention was to get the look right with a default set of colors, but ultimately convert them to grayscale and have them "colored" by the game engine using color lookup material for easy palette swaps. I had 54 colors that would be mapped to 54 gray scale values. I created my sprites by pasting my selected colors to the canvas and changing between them using color picker. After much work I get to the stage where I am going to use Color Exchange to swap my colors to grayscale values and I find I have apparently been working with far more than 54 colors all along because the color picker is broken. I put the one blue I had thought I had been working with in the From Color, and the gray value into the To Color, click OK and what do you know, there is a helluva lot of blue still left. I inspect this blue and find it is in fact a dozen different shades of visually identical blue.

note.body:
Okay, I found a way to reproduce what I was talking about. I have a very specific Blue. 0,35,140. It needs to be 0,35,140 to work with my scripts. So I have this image. 

![font](/uploads/9e2960b50f2ff4ef0f7c4870c3014cd9/font.png) 

I am using it as a tileset and I want it to be power of 2. So I open it up with gimp with the intention of pasting it onto a 256x64 canvas with that blue as the background color. I click the background square. I use the Change Background Color picker to select that blue. But what's this? It won't select that exact blue. If I use the regular old color picker it reports the color as it should be RGB: 0,35,140 Hex 00238c. But using the color picker within Change Background Color will only give me RGB: 0.0, 33.6, 142.2 Hex 00228e (the RGB values are for 0..255 HSV, Hex is the same no matter if it's LCh or 0..100)

So I click okay and now the Active Background Color box has a magenta triangle. I don't know why this is, nor do I know why it is that if I use this image ![AA](/uploads/ad05ced7078f0cbc804e0c0d0e9303b8/AA.png) to change the background color I don't get the magenta triangle (it's the same blue) but in either case, after if I click File>New I will end up with a new image with a background color the color picker reports as 0,34,142 not 0,35,140.

I know I can work around this playing with threshold settings in my scripts, but man does it just irk me when I can't work with precise color values.

edit:

I managed to stop this from happening by going into Color Management and selecting my monitor's color profile. I don't know why this would fix this. Wouldn't it just alter what I see on my monitor, not the actual color values reported by gimp?

note.body: @ellestone okay I guess it's not a bug, just a strange implementation having two different behaviors for what appears to be the same tool. I can't see any situation where someone would want their monitor's inaccuracies being taken into account with a tool whose entire purpose is to copy over exact color data. If you were going to eyeball it you'd just use the color wheel.

events.target_title: Mouse pointer stuttering over the calendar

note.body:
@vanvugt ah, of course.

The actual problem might actually be `/usr/lib/evolution-data-server/evolution-alarm-notify`. Once the gnome processes have died, it leaves and consumes 100% CPU and is constantly allocating more and more memory. But this might not be anything regarding GNOME though. @vanvugt , do you also have high CPU usage with the said process?

events.target_title: Mouse pointer stuttering over the calendar

note.body:
I found a solution to the problem (at least for me):

For some reason, while configuring AppArmor a couple days ago, the audit framework had seemingly overwritten some of my time zone files inside `/usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe`. It had for example overwritten my current time zone file (`/usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/Helsinki`) and also some of the other time zone files. I found this because my system clock was off by 3 hours.

Once I replaced the files with original ones from another Arch installation on my laptop, the high CPU usage with GNOME calendar is not present anymore.

events.target_title: Nested popup windows crash mutter on close
Nested popup windows crash mutter on close

note.body:
I tried both mutter 3.32.2 and mutter 3.33.4.

I quickly sketched a demo for you. And it is located here - https://github.com/msisov/mutter-bug.

Please refer to these instructions from the commit message -

>     .... when a nested popup window is created with explicit grab,
>     it can be hidden by destroying xdg_popup and xdg_surface objects
>     and committing null buffer to the wl_surface (wl_surface is kept).
>     
>     But once it is created without explicit grab, it is not hidden and mutter crashes
>     if another buffer is attached to the main popup
>     
>     To use this demo, compile it with:
>       $ make demo
>     
>     Then run with explicit grab
>       $ ./demo --with-grab
>     
>     Once demo starts, a light-blue square appears. Then,
>     1) Press with a left mouse button on the square and release the button
>     2) Another yellow square will appear (it will be created as a popup window)
>     3) Press again on the appeared square or on the existing one.
>     4) Another red square will appear (as a nested popup window, which parent is previous popup).
>     5) Press on any of the squares, the read square must disappear.
>     6) Press again on any of the squares, the yellow square becomes black.
>     
>     Then run without grab
>       $ ./demo --without-grab
>     
>     Once demo starts, a light-blue square appears (NOTE that mutter will crash). Then,
>     1) Press with a left mouse button on the square and release
>     2) Another yellow square will appear (it will be created as a popup window)
>     3) Press again on the appeared square or on the existing one.
>     4) Another red square will appear.
>     5) Press on any of the squares, the read square must disappear (but
>        it DOES NOT DISAPPEAR IN MUTTER. Weston compositor reacts correctly, though).
>     6) Press again and mutter crashes (in Weston compositor, it becomes black).

note.body:
Hi Michael,\
Thank you for looking into this.

Although there isn't any local user (not listed under /etc/passwd), the username can still be added to wheel under /etc/group.
I've tested this by rebooting into single user mode and editing the /etc/group file. [^1]

Does that address your concerns?

Thank you.

Cheers,\
rodolfo

[^1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1576053#c1

Is there a way to recover codes from the filesystem?

note.body:
I built it myself, but Flatpak often stores user data in ~/.var/app/APPANAME

This is a good place to start. 

If it isn't there, another place it could be is ~/.config/Authenticator

I wish you luck! I just submitted feedback that would prevent this exact situation from being an issue :)

events.target_title: Filter/Distorts/Mosaic is very slow
Filter/Distorts/Mosaic is very slow (when processed in chunks)

note.body:
I cannot fully agree with preview notes. One can easily see that split preview finishes after first or second row while full preview is rendered line by line sector by sector to the end. Also if split axis is moved there is line rendering.

Proposal: (I’ll move it to proposals if confirmed.)

Full preview for image of 2160 × 2880 size is slow using 155 size tiles. Furthermore if there is need to mosaic bigger images full preview become useless in actual state. Maybe the window preview (as in 2.8) could exists alongside with live and split previews so one could preview some crucial part of image to confirm rendered mosaic instead of waiting for render by line rendering.

There is already option to set vertical split axis so there could be at least 1 more for horizontal axis and furthermore 2 more for each of directions to bring option to make a region previews.
